11:19 am
PM

The post-mortem on GBP’s alarming overnight slide indicates that the move was on high volume so it’s
hard to justify this as a fat-finger move, more a one-way market where selling was exacerbated by a
cascade of stop-loss activity, including from option market makers. Based upon a trade low of 1.15, the peak
overnight fall was three-quarters as large Brexit night itself (9% vs 12%).
We don’t think it’s particularly informative to try to attribute the move to any specific overnight news
catalyst. Instead, the price action is consistent with the risk we have been flagging throughout the Brexit
process of a deeper and higher volatility adjustment in GBP should longer-term foreign investors start to
repatriate GBP exposure, something they didn’t do either in the lead up to the referendum or in the immediate
aftermath. Many investors it seems were awaiting clarity from the government about what type of Brexit it
would prioritise, and many presumably were hoping for a softer Brexit that minimized the longer-term economic
damage. But such hopes were dashed at the Conservative Party conference last weekend, and it’s not
unreasonable to attribute the subsequent 4% drop in the pound to some of these investors starting to reassess
their positions."

PM

The spotlight has turned on the potential for hard Brexit following news
flow from the Conservative Party Conference suggesting PM May’s
negotiation will prioritise UK sovereignty and controls over immigration,
potentially at the expense of free market access

BE

Sterling’s weakness has generated a significant outperformance of UK
breakevens. Aside from this channel, however, the full implications of a
refocus on hard Brexit have been largely looked through

BE

Comments from Prime Minister May and Chancellor Hammond have
materially increased the likelihood of a shift in the policy mix away from
monetary towards fiscal policy

BE

Even without assuming additional fiscal easing, a shallower trajectory of
deficit reduction would imply an additional GBP 10bn funding requirement
this fiscal year and GBP 30-40bn from 2017-18 onwards relative to the
March DMO projections. Greater focus on fiscal policy should lead the UK
to underperform, and we recommend going short 30Y UK vs US

BE

Resilient data flow is making it more difficult for the MPC to be dovish,
while recent MPC speak has focused on potential downside risks in the
medium term, but shied away from calling for additional easing at this
point. With the potential for dovish MPC tone to reduce further, we
maintain the short Nov-17 MPC vs long Feb-17

11:27 am
BE

Concern of hard Brexit has generated widening pressures on GBP FRA-OIS
basis, with reduced liquidity support in the form of a move away from
weekly ILTR operations and limited take-up so far from the TFS likely to
also have a role. However, the likelihood of BoE intervention should basis
widen significantly suggests wideners represent an unclear Brexit hedge

BE

From a trade perspective, the strength in breakevens over the week is
beginning to look stretched and the potential for a short term pull back
leads us to maintain the short 10Y real rate. Into upcoming October supply,
and given better covers at long end APF buybacks, we maintain the long
15Y vs 30Y swap spread box

11:39 am
BE

Trading: The demand impact from terrorist and other events has been well articulated and the growth in supply well known, but the Q4 revenue per seat decline at 8.7% was weak. Passenger volumes grew by 6.1% in Q4, in line with the expansion in capacity. At constant currency, cost per seat (ex fuel) fell by 1.1%, better than the 0.8% we had expected, but this was more than offset by FX. The FY16 tax charge is likely to be in the low double digits against our 20% forecast. September’s trading was also softer than we had anticipated with a 2.0pp decline in load factor to 91.1%.
Outlook: easyJet expects to grow capacity by 8% in FY17, 1-2pp lower than competitor growth on its routes, with cost per seat at constant currency (ex fuel) up around 1%, excluding a number of aircraft sale and leaseback transactions and one-off costs associated with the set-up of a European AOC, changes to the organisational structure and union negotiations. The total FX impact for FY17 is expected to be around £90m. We adjust our forecasts accordingly, downgrading FY17e PBT by 18% to £471m. EasyJet remains committed to its target of flat unit cost per seat in FY19 vs FY15, ex-fuel and constant currency.
Valuation & Recommendation: We remain concerned at the level of capacity growth (at the wrong point in the cycle) and fear a further demand impact from sterling weakness and Brexit uncertainty. We therefore assume a constant currency decline in revenue per seat of 7.5% for FY17e. We have not assumed any additional cost savings although they clearly need to be achieved. We reduce our Target Price to 950p but retain our HOLD recommendation given the low multiples the stock now trades on.

BE

And MOST.

BE

We remain EW on easyJet. easyJet has an enviable market position in several key
hubs and country markets, but on balance, its strong bases in the UK, France,
Italy and Switzerland are now under pressure from encroaching peer
competition. While we see potential from cost base flexibility and capital
structure updates in the medium term, increased capacity in the Winter season
will likely keep pressures on yield. Valuation is not particularly compelling at
10.4x our calendar 2017 EPS forecast.
Our bull & bear estimates have also been updated to reflect the FY16/17/18
rebase and new fuel & FX forecasts. Our bull case moves from 1520p to 1490p
(down 2%) and our bear case from 560p to 530p (down 5.4%).

11:40 am
BE

And Deutsche, on the sector view.

BE

Comments from the road:
(1) Investors are in two camps – those that have given up on the sector and
those that are looking for the next triggers that could see the sector perform
(2) The consensual view is very much that Ryanair is the structural winner and
should be bought on weakness. A key trigger that many await however is
management initiation of a share buyback. There is a split on whether RYA will
reduce its guidance at H1 results with the small majority believing that
management will make its numbers. We agree RYA is a structural winner, but
see near-term volatility on industry overcapacity hence HOLD.
(3) Low willingness to incrementally short Lufthansa and AFKLM (for fear of
being too late) albeit there is very little positivity on them either
(4) Discussions focused on what could be the next possible positive triggers for
the sector; could it be: (i) management teams aggressively talking about
capacity cuts at Q3, (ii) management teams eventually indicating a slowing
rate of negative yield growth, (iii) capacity growth actually reducing below 4-
5%, (iv) earnings momentum flattening and/or (v) valuation
(5) Since EV/EBITDAR and PE valuations are not really holding, some investors
are beginning to dust off price to book and price to asset value metrics
(6) Industry overcapacity, at least over winter 2015/2016, is well-known

11:41 am
PM

IN a sector note from Michael Briest

PM

The UK referendum result – a European (not just a UK) challenge
Q2 saw few visible effects from the UK referendum on trading within our Software
universe. However, the vote was held at the end of the quarter and as its importance
sinks-in, we think investors are still concerned that an effect will be evident in Q3, or
later. UBS Evidence Lab surveyed 301 IT decision-makers in the UK, France and
Germany as to the impact of the referendum on IT spending. The referendum was
reported to have negatively impacted IT budgets, leading to 15% reporting that they
had cancelled projects and 22% that they had implemented a hiring freeze or
headcount reduction plan in IT. While the UK-based respondents were more affected
than those in France or Germany, purely domestic UK businesses were less affected
than those French or German businesses with a meaningful (20%-plus) UK sales base.

PM

Here's the Fidessa bit -- at the end

11:42 am
PM

Referendum effects – still a risk to consider
Sterling and the Euro weakened sharply against the US$ at the end of Q2, and while
28% reported greater-than-normal discounts being offered at the end of June, 42%
reported that vendors told them to anticipate higher prices in the future. Both tactics
were successful at converting sales, which might help explain the modest impact of the
referendum on Q2 close rates within our coverage. More of those surveyed regarded
the referendum result as a negative than a positive for IT budgets, but there are many
other drivers of investment which are outweighing it: IT budget plans for 2017 look
healthy at a mean 5.6%, albeit are stronger in France and Germany (both 6.1%) than
the UK (4.6%). On the back of this, we are willing to look out to 2018 to base our
price targets on, leading to several changes (as summarised below). Of note, we
downgrade Aveva to Neutral and Fidessa to Sell on valuation grounds.

PM

Shares to focus on for Q3 and beyond
We expect SAP to report an in-line quarter: While it was back-end loaded, we believe
S/4 take-up remains healthy and some large deals were closed. We highlight Micro
Focus and Sophos as attractive names in the UK mid-cap space, and with the UBS
Evidence Lab Survey showing that the Financial Services sector was most-affected by
the referendum result, and notwithstanding a likely solid Q3 following the Bank of
Ireland deal, reiterate our Sell ratings on Temenos (and add Fidessa today).

There's also, to be fair, a section two on the building suppliers.

11:47 am
BE

BE

The gist here is that FX doesn't matter very much to the housebuilders, except on a few cost lines such as imported labour.

BE

The UK housebuilders' profits are relatively unaffected by currency moves, with the
exception of higher costs for a few imported building products (eg, timber & tiles). The
building materials and distribution companies are more affected by currency moves
given their higher exposure to overseas markets. While transaction impacts are generally
not hugely material, input costs are generally increasing as a result of currency moves,
which will present a challenge to pass on in a market that is expected to become more
difficult. Assuming the merchants can pass on the cost increases, they should be
beneficiaries of a return to price inflation. A number of companies would have significant
translation boosts from a weaker sterling.

11:48 am
BE

Therefore, what we're seeing here is a hard Brexit effect on housing volumes.

BE

Or the anticipation thereof.

BE

I'm going to quote Robin Hardy at Shore again, even though this comment's a couple od days old.

11:50 am
BE

At the Tory Conference in Birmingham there is a suggestion that £5bn will be made available to help build more new homes. Is this new and additional money or just a re-packaging of funds already identified? We suspect that it is largely the latter. We have seen programmes such as ‘Get Britain Building’ and ‘Kick Start’ in various forms over the last 6 years plus there are already substantial programmes in place to release more publically owned ‘brownfield’ land.

Therefore, we believe it would be wrong to believe that this is likely to make any difference as this is not, in our view, stimulus. Any stimulus for housing needs to be both active and incremental and this looks to be neither. Programmes like ‘Kickstart’ were aimed at making sites that were too difficult or expensive to develop viable. However, the changes to land supply under the NPPF mean that house builder are able to secure enough land without development issues such that this help is not needed as those difficult sites are much less likely to be developed.

Also the bulk of the problem land that the house builders owned since before the financial crisis and that would have benefited from such assistance is largely now built and sold with the poor profits or losses rolled into the substantial profits being made on newer sites. If there is going to be anything significant and meaningful on housing it needs to be much more focused on active supply (putting resources into housing associations, enabling SME house builders to be active again, boosting PRS and having the state actually build housing again) rather than passive measures such as the ones now highlighted now.

If, however, this was the sum total of what the government intends to do and real policy change is not on the agenda, ironically that would be more positive for the house builders as it would avoid the creation of materially more competition, which we believe to be the main threat to the ‘golden’ trading environment the house builders have enjoyed for the last 2-3 years.

11:58 am
PM

( kodojin -- will do later)

BE

Bernstein incoming

BE

PM Teresa May recently talked about potential interventions in a number of markets including energy. Given a number of interventions in train post the recent 2 year CMA investigation, the key question is how much beyond the CMA actions is the Government willing to go and in this note, we outline the potential scenarios.

The worst case scenario: Extend a price cap to all customers on a Standard Variable Tariff. ~70% of customers. We think it is unlikely that the Government would take such a big interventionist measure, as it will effectively disregard the CMA's opinion about the disproporationality of the measure. Also, this measure does not actually help new entrants, as customers are likely to get even more disengaged. In any case, a head-room margin of 3%-4% will likely be included to avoid distortions to competition

Moderate scenario: Extend the cap to more vulnerable customers ~8% of customers in addition to the 16% covered by PPM cap: The Government could extend the CMA's regulated price cap to customers on 'Warm Home Discount' as well, covering a total of 20%-24% of customers (assuming some degree of overlap between the two categories).

Best case scenario: The Government implements the CMA interventions: As the CMA remedies have not yet been implemented, getting them implemented well and potentially faster could be the approach that the Government takes and still take credit for market 'interventions'.

11:59 am
BE

And Morgan Stanley, which downgrades.

BE

By embracing the consumer and marginalising commodity-
exposed businesses, Centrica hopes to capture greater value,
which could drive up its multiples in line with consumer
stocks. We draw on BT as a precedent. Excluding commodities,
rapid upside is unlikely, and with valuation fair we move EW.

BE

Consumer the new focus, commodities marginalised: Whilst many may struggle
to be enamoured by a UK energy supply business, this remains Centrica's jewel. It
continues to deliver strong cash flow even with political focus and CMA
investigations, and new management views it as key to a dramatic reshaping of its
value proposition, which could in time upend the consensus view of the stock as
simply a proxy to the oil price. Telcos have shown that broadening reach and
bundling products can lead to stickier, and more valuable, customers.

11:59 am
BE

The BT of 2009 as a template? There are many overlaps between Centrica
today and BT in 2009. (1) New management moved focus from EPS to cash flow.
(2) Cost cutting helped drive improved cash flows at BT. (3) There were many
question marks around BT's core customer business – we see the same for
Centrica today. (4) BT actively pursued moves to bundle and create greater
customer value – could we see the same opportunities for Centrica with Hive
products as Smart meters are rolled out and customers become more energy
aware? BT's strong re-rating shows the upside that could await Centrica.

BE

Can Centrica maximise value from its consumer embrace? Assuming a stable
commodity outlook, we stress test the profitability of new customer facing
business. In our bull case, we assume a "material" contribution from new
businesses by 2020 – on "consumer-type" multiples (20x P/E, 4% dividend yield)
this drives our 330p bull case (c.40% implied upside). However, if investment
yields no profits, a lower P/E (12.5x, in line with history) and yield (6.5%) on lower
EPS and DPS drives our 140p bear case (c.40% downside).

BE

Move to EW, prefer SSE: The market appears to believe in some growth at
Centrica today – the shares trade over 1SD above long-term P/E average, but still
in line with oil – something that should decouple in time. Our bull case sees
c.40% upside, but is dependent on long-term consumer upside, while visibility
remains low. Our base case EPS CAGR 2016-20e is c4% (1% ex new businesses),
and drives our new 225p price target (implying 3% downside). For now, we prefer
the visibility at SSE (Overweight)

12:04 pm
BE

Profit Warning & update on financial position
Group SPWD at CER were down 2% in Q3. The base business
has deteriorated, down 8% in Q3 (Key Accounts +2%). Bearings
& Power Transmission sales were 6% lower YoY in Q3. £30m
inventory reduction target was achieved but FY impact on GM
now expected to be 200bps (vs 80bps impact in H1). The
company have also cut their FY sales expectations and the
Nordics business has deteriorated in H2. The Group has
incurred an operating loss in Q3 and no longer expects to report
an underlying profit for the FY (H1 PBT £5.0m).

BE

 Pulling back on vending roll-out to conserve cash.
 Expect to conclude business review in November.
 Average net debt £50m-£60m higher than reported at period end, funded
from RCF draw-down and non-recourse factoring. Without amendments,
likely to breach covenants at 31st December.
 Stand-by underwriting agreed for a rights issue of up to £100m, to be
launched no later than the prelims in Q1-2017.
 FY dividend scrapped.
 Forecasts: Very little visibility on the FY out-turn. The combination of the
reduced rebates, lower sales assumption and Nordics deterioration cuts our
FY2016 PBT by £17.5m. We now anticipate a FY Loss before tax of £5m.
FY2017 will depend on the conclusions of the business review, cost reductions
and arresting the decline in bearings sales. Pending the review in November,
we are assuming no more than break-even PBT in FY2017.
 Whilst the business has lost focus in recent years, the early conclusions of the
business review have validated the Group's unique European footprint and
strong market position in a number of geographic markets. However, the
turnaround will not be a quick one.
 We are cutting our target price to 60p.

undefined

BE

Anyway, Goldman starts coverage today with a price target that's very, very high.

BE

We initiate coverage on GWPH, a pre-commercial-stage biopharmaceutical
company focused on cannabis-based therapies in central nervous system
(CNS) disorders. GWPH’s lead asset is Epidiolex for Dravet Syndrome (DS)
and Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome (LGS), two severe orphan epilepsies, which
are de-risked post three positive Ph 3 studies. We anticipate a solid launch
trajectory (greater than 1K US patient bolus) with widespread off-label use in non-
DS/LGS epilepsies – we model $1.6bn in WW sales, of which 51% is derived
from US pediatric off-label use (assumes sales cliff in 2026 and 2028). A
barrage of pipeline catalysts should drive shares higher in 4Q16.

12:08 pm
BE

We expect GWPH shares to trade higher on the following pipeline catalysts:
(1) publication of Epidiolex Ph 3 study in Dravet syndrome in a top-tier
medical journal in 4Q, (2) American Epilepsy Society (Dec 2-6) meeting data
to reinforce the clinical and safety profile, (3) Epidiolex Ph 3 study initiation
in infantile spasms in 4Q, (4) Sativex Ph 2 data in cerebral palsy spasticity
and THC:CBD Ph 2a data in recurrent glioblastoma in 4Q, (5) Epidiolex NDA
submission in 1H17, (6) CBDV Ph 2 data in adult focal seizures/epilepsy in
1Q17, (7) AAN (Apr 22-28) data update, (8) initiation of CBDV Ph 2 study in
autism spectrum disorders in 1H17, (9) Epidiolex Phase 3 dose-ranging
Dravet study data in 2017, and (10) Epidiolex Phase 3 data in tuberous
sclerosis complex in 2H17. We believe GWPH will submit the Epidiolex in
DS/LGS US regulatory filing in 1H17 (we assume US/EU launches in 2Q18/
3Q18; however, 2H17 is possible). Per KOL feedback, there is substantial
interest from the medical community and patients for Epidiolex in all
treatment-resistant epilepsies (TREs) in pediatric and adult populations.
